title: Is a discharged debt still recoverable after bankruptcy
question: I had a car loan charge off discharged through a chapter 7 bankruptcy. The car was involved in an accident. My insurance company paid the finance company 2500 dollars because they still were the lien holder of record. Did I still owe them that money or should we have received the money for the value of the car.
answers: My colleagues are 100% correct. The insurance pay off goes to the lien holder.

I agree with Mr. Rausa. Your Chapter 7 discharged your personal liability (unless you signed a Reaffirmation Agreement) meaning the lien holder cannot come after you personally since you received a discharge, however, the lien holder still retains a security interest in the vehicle. If the vehicle was totaled then the insurance company was correct in paying the lien holder.

A charge off is an accounting principle. Your car lender still retained a security interest in the vehicle regardless of your Chapter 7 Discharge. Your discharge only relates to your personal liability, not insurance proceeds. You do not owe the lien holder any money, unless you signed a reaffirmation agreement that was approved by the Court.

By Law, the insurance carrier has to pay the lien holder.
